subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] why  'why'?
msgSnippet: I m afraid I didn t understand the question right. I m interested in several alternative alphabets and, if I remember the shapes of the letters, I sometimes
messageBody:
I'm afraid I didn't understand the question right.
I'm interested in several alternative alphabets and, if I remember the
shapes of the letters, I sometimes forget which keyword is associated with
which phoneme in a given system.
Since the consonants of way and why are pronounced alike in many dialects, I
understood the question had to do with their diphtongs.

BTW why did my answer appear only a half day after I sent it?


Jean-François Colson wrote:
> Here are just a few minimal pairs (I don't have enough time to look
> for all those in my dictionaries):
>
> spate / spite
> day / die
> lay / lie
> way / why (pronounced with the same consonant in many dialects)
> hey / hi
> late / light
> mate / might
> they / thy
>
> I'm sure you could find a lot more minimal pairs if you think a
> little about it.
>
> BTW Do you know the joke about the two Australians in a hospital room?
>
> "Did you come here to die?" (= today)
> "Yes to die." (= yesterday)
>
>
> peter_r_guinness wrote:
>> Can anyone find a minimal pair for 'way' and 'why'? If not then they
>> both represent allophones of the same phomene.
>> Since we seem to agree that we should use phonemic principles by
>> employing lexical sets, doesn't that mean that one of them is
>> redundant and that it should be deprecated? Eg: 'why' should be
>> removed from the alphabet.
>>
>> peter
>>
>>
>>
